and of course answering your questions along the way key drivers this is the y for inspector
you have an eight you have agent and agentless tools for deploying there's a lot of configuration involved you need
to have a good understanding of your fleet to know about new instances that are deployed or spun up across hundreds
of accounts tooling needs to be configured with access knowing all about the ip ranges
having agents for those agent-based deployments configured and then deployed
there's a lot of work that needs to be done up front to put the infrastructure in place to be
identified to be able to begin identifying vulnerabilities include without the dynamic nature of
workloads and you have a complex environment to manage you need them
then to notify and chase down teams when you have a finding to get them to remediate it new vulnerabilities are
released frequently and you have a lag in time when you're looking at periodic scanning
to find and identify those new vulnerabilities so frequently it's a snapshot in time
not near real time inspector provides the ability for operations or infosec teams to have
confidence to monitor near real time and act on those vulnerabilities
and then finally you're able to demonstrate compliance to your risking compliance team or audit groups
this is where amazon inspector comes in it's a vulnerability management service that continuously scans your aws
workloads for vulnerabilities it automatically discovers and scans amazon ec2 instances
and container images residing in amazon elastic container registry amazon ecr
for sales for vulnerabilities as well as unintended network exposures when an issue is discovered inspector
creates a finding and from there you're able to take action receive notifications and such and where to look for
remediation
so how does it work going through i'll go through an overview here and then we'll see it in action in the
demo you first enable inspector at an organization's level from there there's different
configurations you can have to set for discovery and scanning it works off of cves from multiple data
sources databases that are continually updated and then provides near real-time results in discovering and scanning
it then iterates through new workloads and updates vulnerability as and
publishes those results as it finds them we add additional context
beyond what's published in the cves to enhance and provide further content
around the criticality of that vulnerability specific to your account to help you prioritize an act and then
it's published out to inspector security hub amazon ecr and then to eventbridge and
from there you can use eventbridge to integrate with other aws services or third-party tools and utilities in order
to take action
so before we jump into the benefits um click do we have any questions so far

by ssm so the previous version of inspector required its own um agent uh to be deployed in order to
manage ec2 instances so today if you have ec2 instances that are managed by the systems manager agent
uh inspector is going to automatically be aware of those and start scanning them so you do need to have
that agent installed on your ec2 instances for container workloads no agent needs to be deployed it's going to

you can be confident and have it configured that inspector is going to start scanning that account as soon as it's created
you have the ability to delegate the administration in the organization so you can gain centralized visibility

how it works discovery is automated and continual driven by updates from new or updated

for an organization within specific accounts and as i mentioned it's it's
really the key here is every time there's a new vulnerability release to your environment it's scan it's scanning
across all of your instances and images to make sure that you're not exposed to that vulnerability
and again the instances are prioritized with contextualized scoring
not just from the cbe but as i mentioned from our own uh analysis and being able to understand
the reachability of those instances from the public internet if it has any network gateways acls or security groups
it can raise the score or lower the score based on that accessibility
and then you can automate workflows and take action so you can automatically notify
different development teams application teams uh or take further action in order to isolate um
an instance or something that based upon the criticality of that vulnerability that you find
there's a lot of workflow and there's a lot more apis than in the previous version

being able to work with your operations teams and expedite and prioritize
